items.answer: The Integrated Lake Albert Resource Development Project, including the Tilenga development and the EACOP pipeline, is a project consistent with this strategy of low-dead-end projects that are the most efficient in terms of greenhouse gas emissions. In particular, the greenhouse gas emissions intensity of this project is 13 kgCO2/boe, i.e. less than 1 MtCO2eq/year at the plateau (Scope 1 + 2), corresponding to a level much lower than the current average of TotalEnergies' oil production which is of the order of 19 kgCO2/bep. These figures do not include indirect greenhouse gas emissions related to customers' use of energy products produced and sold for final use (Scope 3) from oil produced by Tilenga (and Kingfisher).

The integrated project to develop the Lake Albert resources, which consists of the Tilenga development and the EACOP pipeline, is consistent with our strategy to focus on projects with both a low breakeven point and low greenhouse gas footprint. This project's GHG emissions intensity comes to 13 kg CO2/boe, which is well below the current average of our oil portfolio of around 20 kg/boe.

For the Tilenga project, in line with International Finance Corporation (IFC) standards and national legislation, TotalEnergies committed to offsetting residual impacts to achieve a net positive gain for biodiversity and ecosystem services in and around Murchison Falls.

For example, during meetings that took place in December 2019 and January 2020, TotalEnergies EP Uganda had the opportunity to remind the authorities concerned of its commitment to respect for human rights. On 25 May 2021, TotalEnergies EP Uganda was informed by the International Federation for Human Rights (FIDH) that a representative of the NGO AFIEGO and a foreign journalist who were carrying out investigations with people in the area where the Tilenga project is to be developed, had been arrested by the Police in the Buliisa region of Uganda. Upon receipt of this alert from the NGO, TotalEnergies EP Uganda teams intervened with the Ugandan authorities. They also took the initiative to inform the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (UN OHCHR), based in Uganda. On May 28, 2021, the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of TotalEnergies SE wrote a letter to the President of the Republic of Uganda to share his concerns in this regard and to request that the rights of data subjects be respected, emphasizing the importance that TotalEnergies attaches to press freedom and open dialogue with its stakeholders

To-date - 10,000 people in the Tilenga footprint area, have been held over 3 years, to explain the land acquisition process and ensure that all interested and affected parties are informed and involved throughout the process.
Land acquisition process designed by the Tilenga team and implemented closely with both Governments, specialized partners and local stakeholders.

For the RAPs 2 to 5 of the Tilenga project that are in progress, it is proposed to each person to choose the format of his compensation: either a financial compensation, or a purchase of a land of equivalent surface by TotalEnergies on his behalf. This option has been set up in order to protect each person impacted.
The implementation of the Tilenga and EACOP projects requires the implementation of a land acquisition programme covering approximately 6,400 hectares.
For the Tilenga project, the compensation implementation process has been completed for RAP 1, covering the site of future treatment facilities. This RAP 1 concerned 622 PAPs.

Land is permanently being acquired by Government of Uganda (GoU) through the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Development (MEMD). Land will be vested in Uganda Land Commission (ULC) on the behalf of GoU and then leased to the Tilenga Project.

There are still other Tilenga packages for which tendering has not been completed. Due to the interdependence of the project packages, specific contract values constitute sensitive commercial information that can only be shared publicly at a later date when all procurement is substantially concluded. In the meantime, all recommendations to award containing specific contract values have been scrutinized by TotalEnergiesâ€™ management, joint venture partners and Government.
The Tilenga project is estimated to cost a total of USD$ 4 to 5 Billion. The EPSCC and drilling packages scopes for which CLOAs have been issued account for 70-75% of the total value.

The Tilenga and EACOP projects will create around 11,000 direct local jobs created during the construction phase and 900 during the production phase (approximately 47,000 indirect jobs will be also created during construction and 2,400 during production)
Priority will be given to local companies, which are expected to have around $1.7 billion in contracts during the Tilenga and EACOP construction phase.
